articles.content: In order to make the choices required to achieve his goals, a man needs the constant, automatized awareness of the principle which the anti-concept “duty” has all but obliterated in his mind: the principle of causality—specifically, of Aristotelian final causation (which, in fact, applies only to a conscious being), i.e., the process by which an end determines the means, i.e., the process of choosing a goal and taking the actions necessary to achieve it.
articles.attribution:
“Causality Versus Duty,”
Philosophy: Who Needs It, 99

articles.content:
Only a process of final causation—i.e., the process of choosing a goal, then
taking the steps to achieve it—can give logical continuity, coherence and
meaning to a man’s actions.
articles.attribution:
“Basic Principles of Literature,”
The Romantic Manifesto, 82
